pages.text: Idmonarachne is a tetrapulmonate arachnid known from the latest Carboniferous of Montceau-les-Mines, France. It was described by Russell Garwood et al. in 2016, who recognized it as a unique animal, outside of any previously known order of arthropods, extinct or extant, despite an obvious resemblance to spiders. Preserved in 3 dimensions, CT scanning revealed immaculate details in the fossil.

They found that it had neither the spinnerets expected of a spider, nor the long flagellum of their closest extinct relatives, the Uraraneidans. Their cladistic analysis instead suggested that it belonged to a sister lineage to spiders, representing their closest known relatives outside the Araneae. It seems likely that the Carboniferous was a period of significant diversification among arachnids, as Idmonarachne represents one among several lineages which make their first appearance during this period.
